ocr.line: ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι-
ocr.sentence: Πεπτωκότος γὰρ ἐν τῇ μάχῃ τοῦ Ἀχιλλέως ἐδόκουν Αἴας τε καὶ Ὀδυσσεὺς ἐπ’ αὐτῷ πλέον u ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι- νομένων περὶ τῶν ὅπλων, κρατεῖ Ὀδυσσεὺς, ὅθεν ὁ Αας, τῆς κρίσεως μὴ Tuyav, παρακεκίνηται zul διέ- φθαρται τὴν γνώμην, ὦστε ἐφαπτόμενος τῶν ποιμνίων δοκεῖν τοὺς Ἕλληνας διαχρήσασθαι, καὶ Ta μὲν ἀνεῖλε Tüv τετραπόδων, za δὲ δήσας ἀπάγει ἐπὶ τὴν σκηνὴν, ἐν οἷς ἐστι καὶ κριός τις ἔξοχος, ὃν Wero εἶναι Ὀδυσ- cu, iv δήσας ἐμαστίγωσεν, ὅθεν καὶ τῇ ἐπιγραφῇ πρόςκειται ὁ Μαστιγοφόρος, ἢ πρὸς ἀντιδιαστολὴν τοῦ Λοκροῦ.
ocr.region: To δρᾶμα τῆς τρωϊκῆς ἐστι πραγματείας, ὥςπερ οἱ Ἀντηνορίδαι καὶ Αἰχμαλωτίδες nal Ἑλένης ἁρπαγὴ καὶ Μέμνον. Πεπτωκότος γὰρ ἐν τῇ μάχῃ τοῦ Ἀχιλλέως ἐδόκουν Αἴας τε καὶ Ὀδυσσεὺς ἐπ’ αὐτῷ πλέον u ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι- νομένων περὶ τῶν ὅπλων, κρατεῖ Ὀδυσσεὺς, ὅθεν ὁ Αας, τῆς κρίσεως μὴ Tuyav, παρακεκίνηται zul διέ- φθαρται τὴν γνώμην, ὦστε ἐφαπτόμενος τῶν ποιμνίων δοκεῖν τοὺς Ἕλληνας διαχρήσασθαι, καὶ Ta μὲν ἀνεῖλε Tüv τετραπόδων, za δὲ δήσας ἀπάγει ἐπὶ τὴν σκηνὴν, ἐν οἷς ἐστι καὶ κριός τις ἔξοχος, ὃν Wero εἶναι Ὀδυσ- cu, iv δήσας ἐμαστίγωσεν, ὅθεν καὶ τῇ ἐπιγραφῇ πρόςκειται ὁ Μαστιγοφόρος, ἢ πρὸς ἀντιδιαστολὴν τοῦ Λοκροῦ. Δκαίαρχος de Αἴαντος θάνατον Enı- άφει· ἐν δὲ ταῖς διδασκαλίαις ψιλῶς Αἴας ava- γγραπται.
groundtruth.line: ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι-
groundtruth.sentence: Πεπτωκότος γὰρ ἐν τῇ μάχῃ τοῦ Ἀχιλλέως ἐδόκουν Αἴας τε καὶ Ὀδυσσεὺς ἐπ’ αὐτῷ πλέον τι ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι- νομένων περὶ τῶν ὅπλων, κρατεῖ Ὀδυσσεὺς, ὅθεν ὁ Αἴας, τῆς κρίσεως μὴ τυχὼν, παρακεκίνηται καὶ διέ- φθαρται τὴν γνώμην, ὥστε ἐφαπτόμενος τῶν ποιμνίων δοκεῖν τοὺς Ἕλληνας διαχρήσασθαι, καὶ τὰ μὲν ἀνεῖλε τῶν τετραπόδων, τὰ δὲ δήσας ἀπάγει ἐπὶ τὴν σκηνὴν, ἐν οἷς ἐστι καὶ κριός τις ἔξοχος, ὃν ᾤετο εἶναι Ὀδυσ- σέα, ὃν δήσας ἐμαστίγωσεν, ὅθεν καὶ τῇ ἐπιγραφῇ πρόςκειται ὁ Μαστιγοφόρος, ἢ πρὸς ἀντιδιαστολὴν τοῦ Λοκροῦ.
groundtruth.region: Τὸ δρᾶμα τῆς τρωϊκῆς ἐστι πραγματείας, ὥςπερ οἱ Ἀντηνορίδαι καὶ Αἰχμαλωτίδες καὶ Ἑλένης ἁρπαγὴ καὶ Μέμνων. Πεπτωκότος γὰρ ἐν τῇ μάχῃ τοῦ Ἀχιλλέως ἐδόκουν Αἴας τε καὶ Ὀδυσσεὺς ἐπ’ αὐτῷ πλέον τι ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι- νομένων περὶ τῶν ὅπλων, κρατεῖ Ὀδυσσεὺς, ὅθεν ὁ Αἴας, τῆς κρίσεως μὴ τυχὼν, παρακεκίνηται καὶ διέ- φθαρται τὴν γνώμην, ὥστε ἐφαπτόμενος τῶν ποιμνίων δοκεῖν τοὺς Ἕλληνας διαχρήσασθαι, καὶ τὰ μὲν ἀνεῖλε τῶν τετραπόδων, τὰ δὲ δήσας ἀπάγει ἐπὶ τὴν σκηνὴν, ἐν οἷς ἐστι καὶ κριός τις ἔξοχος, ὃν ᾤετο εἶναι Ὀδυσ- σέα, ὃν δήσας ἐμαστίγωσεν, ὅθεν καὶ τῇ ἐπιγραφῇ πρόςκειται ὁ Μαστιγοφόρος, ἢ πρὸς ἀντιδιαστολὴν τοῦ Λοκροῦ. Δικαίαρχος δὲ Αἴαντος θάνατον ἐπι- γράφει· ἐν δὲ ταῖς διδασκαλίαις ψιλῶς Αἴας ἀνα- γέγραπται.
prediction.prompt:
Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:
κἀγὼ 700, ὃς Ta deis ἑκαρτέρουν τότε, βαφῇ σίδηρος ὥς, ἐθηλύνθην στόμα πρὸς τῆςδε τῆς γυναικός· οἰκτείρω δέ νιν χήραν παρ’ ἐχθροῖς, παῖδά τ’ ὀρφανὸν ἀλλ’ el πρός Te λουτρὰ καὶ παρακτίους λειμῶνας, ὡς dv λύμαθ’ ἀγνίσας ἐμὰ μῆνιν βαρεῖαν ἐξαλεύσωμαι θεᾶς· μολών Te, χῶρον ἔνθ’ dv ἀστιβῆ κίχω, κρύψω τόδ’ ἔγχος τοὐμὸν, ἔχθιστον βελῶν, γαίας ὀρύξας ἔνθα μή τις ὄψεται. ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ νὐξ Ἅιδης Te σωζόντων κάτω. ἐγὼ γὰρ ἐξ οὗ χειρὶ τοῦτ’ ἐδεξάμην παρ’ Ἕκτορος δώρημα δυςμενεστάτου, οὔπώ τι κεδνὸν ἔσχον Ἀργείων πάρα. ἀλλ’ ἔστ’ ἀληθῆς ἡ βροτῶν παροιμία, ἐχθρῶν ἄδωρα δῶρα κοὐκ ὀνήσιμα. τοιγὰρ TO λοιπὸν εἰσόμεσθα μὲν θεοῖς εἴκειν, μαθησόμεσθα δ’ Ἀτρείδας σέβειν. ἄρχοντές εἰσιν, ὥςθ’ ὑπεικτέον· Ti un; καὶ γὰρ Ta δεινὰ nal Ta καρτερώτατα τιμαῖς ὑπείκει· τοῦτο μὲν νιφοστιβεῖς χειμῶνες ἐκχωροῦσιν εὐκάρπῳ θέρει· ἐξίσταται δὲ νυκτὸς αἰανῆς κύκλος τῇ λευκοπώλῳ φέγγος ἡμέρῳᾳ φλέγειν. δεινῶν τ’ ἄημα πνευμάτων ἐκοίμισε στένοντα πόντον· ἐν δ’ ὁ παγκρατὴς ὕπνος λύει πεδήσας οὐδ’ ἀεὶ λαβὼν ἔχει. ἡμεῖς δὲ πῶς οὐ γνωσόμεσθα σωφρονεῖν; ἐγὼ δ’, ἐπίσταμαι γὰρ ἀρτίως ὅτι ὅ τ’ ἐχθρὸς ἡμῖν ἐς τοσόνδ’ ἐχθαρτέος, ws καὶ φιλήσων αὖθις· ἔς Te τὸν φίλον τοσαῦθ’ ὑπουργῶν ὠφελεῖν βουλήσομαι,

ocr.sentence: ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ.
ocr.region: JOHNA. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. AOHNA. "dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.
groundtruth.sentence: ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ.
groundtruth.region: ΑΘΗΝΑ. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Ἀεὶ μὲν, ὦ παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά σε πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῶ Αἴαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι καὶ χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆς δε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν ἔθου τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.
prediction.prompt:
Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

From the theory of the dialogue according to the classical interpretation by W.N. Hofweber:

BASILEUS. Ask a question about people, about what's going on right now.

MEN. First tell me one thing, sir. Are you Basileus?

BASILEUS. Yes, according to the antique principle, "to the king belong the young men" [Eur. "Her." 950], young men are under his care; and show of respect, and reverence, and modesty, and obedience – these are what young men should show the leader put in charge of them. 
For there is nothing, Menaechmus, in what you say. That's what laws all have in common.

But you did not understand these basics, my son. I hear the voice of someone who is deeply angry, kicking up a fuss about evil deeds and that son of Pheretiades’ having behaved insolently. Seeing his guest hungry and parched, he'd keep the best food for himself, flaunting it now, and if he does catch wind of a win-win situation, it has to be his way.

PLEISTHENES. Miserable sick man, whom the gods (who delight in quarrels) have sent as a chosen messenger into the world of mortals! What a dreadful state I see you in! How strength and youth have abandoned you! Before you had desired death by gods' reckoning. You had surrendered completely to feasts and games, emptied the table, and were rewarded with all sorts of gifts. What you won was pride! Isn't that so? Weren't you tickled by the golden tinkle and the bracelets filled with dangling pearls? 
What kids enjoy so much, didn't all this make you grow ever stronger and firmer? In a little while you used up the running down the track! Your empty belly always sent you out with spears and your running contests; these are the kind that lead the races. Always to no avail, someone else seemingly was running out in front, never giving up hope of winning once again. You were a winner, but you went for it again and again and came out first in what seemed to be the next to last place, which made you a big sinner against the god who watches over Thessalian horses. The chosen one, though, went on ahead and gained the prize, becoming the winner. This was quite the thing to see! But your futile squandering made you so embittered, that you blasphemed against the gods and fought with everyone and threw yourself on your parents' grave.

And what about your mother? After nursing you and bringing you up, loving you, not benefiting from a good life but always in misery, did you stay quiet when you saw her with nothing? Didn't you figure that she was suffering wretchedly because of

τῃ νέοιο δόμοιο· οὔτ’ ἀνίαν οὔτε νέκυν
θήσει· μέθ’ ἐκείν’ ἢ μοιχὸς ἢ μιαρός·
μύσος γὰρ ἄλλον οὐδεὶς ἄλλα γένοιτο.
Κηδόνα· ἐξ ἐσχάτοις ἀνδράσιν κατὰ δόμοιο
δι’ ὄφελος. ἔνθα δ’ οὔτ’ ἐφορκίσει κακόν ἄλλον

Ὑγειαν ἀρωγὰν ὄψει. ἐμίχεαι δέ τ’ ἐκ δικτύων
ἀναιδή νενρήν, ἕτερον δέ γ’ ἀέκον φθόνον,
ἕρδ’ ἄνω μιᾶς ἐκεῖ θεωρεῖν εὐρύοπα ρωμάς.
Τόδε τοῦ πένθος δαιμόνων αὖ μειλιχίονα
μύθον ἀδάποτον θεοῖς θάμβοισι τε γὰρ ἀνθρώποις,
διηνεκέεσσι μετ᾽ ἐκεῖνα ὅσον ἴδοισιν αἴσχιον,
ὃν ἀΐδιον φαίνε

From the theory of the dialogue according to the classical interpretation by W.N. Hofweber:

BASILEUS. Ask a question about people, about what's going on right now.

MEN. First tell me one thing, sir. Are you Basileus?

BASILEUS. Yes, according to the antique principle, "to the king belong the young men" [Eur. "Her." 950], young men are under his care; and show of respect, and reverence, and modesty, and obedience – these are what young men should show the leader put in charge of them. 
For there is nothing, Menaechmus, in what you say. That's what laws all have in common.

But you did not understand these basics, my son. I hear the voice of someone who is deeply angry, kicking up a fuss about evil deeds and that son of Pheretiades’ having behaved insolently. Seeing his guest hungry and parched, he'd keep the best food for himself, flaunting it now, and if he does catch wind of a win-win situation, it has to be his way.

PLEISTHENES. Miserable sick man, whom the gods (who delight in quarrels) have sent as a chosen messenger into the world of mortals! What a dreadful state I see you in! How strength and youth have abandoned you! Before you had desired death by gods' reckoning. You had surrendered completely to feasts and games, emptied the table, and were rewarded with all sorts of gifts. What you won was pride! Isn't that so? Weren't you tickled by the golden tinkle and the bracelets filled with dangling pearls? 
What kids enjoy so much, didn't all this make you grow ever stronger and firmer? In a little while you used up the running down the track! Your empty belly always sent you out with spears and your running contests; these are the kind that lead the races. Always to no avail, someone else seemingly was running out in front, never giving up hope of winning once again. You were a winner, but you went for it again and again and came out first in what seemed to be the next to last place, which made you a big sinner against the god who watches over Thessalian horses. The chosen one, though, went on ahead and gained the prize, becoming the winner. This was quite the thing to see! But your futile squandering made you so embittered, that you blasphemed against the gods and fought with everyone and threw yourself on your parents' grave.

And what about your mother? After nursing you and bringing you up, loving you, not benefiting from a good life but always in misery, did you stay quiet when you saw her with nothing? Didn't you figure that she was suffering wretchedly because of

ocr.region: JOHNA. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. ΑΙΑΣ. AOHNA. "dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

λίαν θανόντων δὲ πολλάκις κακῶς·
τῶν δὲ σθέων τάχα καὶ τῶν δακρύων
υἱοὶ ἄρχειν ἐκ τεός· ἀλλ᾽ ἐκεϊ λίαν οἱ
ἐξολόθρευται· μόλις μισήκεϊ φρενή·
Κῆρας δ᾽ ὁμοῦ μετὰ θανάτοιο χενική.

prediction.sentence:
δειλότατός τε γ’ ὁ θεῖ’ ἄρ’ ἐμεῖο βίου κινήσας μαχησιάντων ἐκ στρατοῦ, πόλης τε τοῦ μ’ ἄγησι τοῦδήποτ ἐμῇ γαίών, κοινῆς βελόνης τῶν τὰ µόρια ταῖς ἡγεμονίας χέρσαις, ἥσσυαις: ἀλλ’ ἔπανιπεν πυθοίμην, ἥγου τοῦ ὄψειον τ’ οὕνεϊ βάλλειν εἰρύ̣σθ’ ἄγχρι κρητῶν τῶν τὴν νεκάδων ὑπόδουλον αἰσχροκεράνων γην. ‡ὡς ἄρχει δὲ περὶ σπίνον Κουβενὰν Ελλάμων: τιμή, ἄνεσις, γλώσσα τ’, οὐδὲν δέ λήγ’ ὅ τι βροτοῖς ἀγαθόν πόλυνε βρέματα μλών. αὐτίκα σε, τήμερ’ ὄξεια, ὡς ἅνακρυ̃ ῥέζων τὰ σύνδυα, ἄλλως γιγνώτων ἐξαφανίζηται γῆρας καὶ ἄλλησι φαίνεται δῶμα περὶ σπίνον· ὕστερον δὲ οὐ περ λεκτίσεαι πιὼν, ὅτι βλάψουσιν, πἀρδούσας βίσης διανοῖγον ἅπαν, βαλανῷς αὐτῶν τε καὶ ἕρξεων ἄγγελον κατασκοτισµόν. καὶ δαιβόλων καταλείπων ἐρέων ἐν τῶιδε βιβλίωι.

ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

From the theory of the dialogue according to the classical interpretation by W.N. Hofweber:

BASILEUS. Ask a question about people, about what's going on right now.

MEN. First tell me one thing, sir. Are you Basileus?

BASILEUS. Yes, according to the antique principle, "to the king belong the young men" [Eur. "Her." 950], young men are under his care; and show of respect, and reverence, and modesty, and obedience – these are what young men should show the leader put in charge of them. 
For there is nothing, Menaechmus, in what you say. That's what laws all have in common.

But you did not understand these basics, my son. I hear the voice of someone who is deeply angry, kicking up a fuss about evil deeds and that son of Pheretiades’ having behaved insolently. Seeing his guest hungry and parched, he'd keep the best food for himself, flaunting it now, and if he does catch wind of a win-win situation, it has to be his way.

PLEISTHENES. Miserable sick man, whom the gods (who delight in quarrels) have sent as a chosen messenger into the world of mortals! What a dreadful state I see you in! How strength and youth have abandoned you! Before you had desired death by gods' reckoning. You had surrendered completely to feasts and games, emptied the table, and were rewarded with all sorts of gifts. What you won was pride! Isn't that so? Weren't you tickled by the golden tinkle and the bracelets filled with dangling pearls? 
What kids enjoy so much, didn't all this make you grow ever stronger and firmer? In a little while you used up the running down the track! Your empty belly always sent you out with spears and your running contests; these are the kind that lead the races. Always to no avail, someone else seemingly was running out in front, never giving up hope of winning once again. You were a winner, but you went for it again and again and came out first in what seemed to be the next to last place, which made you a big sinner against the god who watches over Thessalian horses. The chosen one, though, went on ahead and gained the prize, becoming the winner. This was quite the thing to see! But your futile squandering made you so embittered, that you blasphemed against the gods and fought with everyone and threw yourself on your parents' grave.

And what about your mother? After nursing you and bringing you up, loving you, not benefiting from a good life but always in misery, did you stay quiet when you saw her with nothing? Didn't you figure that she was suffering wretchedly because of

"dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

Ἀεὶ μὲν, ὦ παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά σε πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῶ Αἴαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι καὶ χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆς δε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν ἔθου τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος ᾖς, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπʼ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

εἰ μὲν θήσω: σκότισιν βασιλεύης ἐν μεγάροις χρυσουνίας, σοὶ δ’ ἐπέλεε παρθενίης ζωὰς ἀνησόμενος ἔνθα ἔμμεναι συγδαίς.

ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:
μή μόνος τελέλομαι ταῦτα κἄστι τις αὐτός: Κατ’ εἶθ’ αὐτὰ δέ, τὰ πάντα ἐάσας πατούμενος τῷ Κεραυνόν, ἥ τ’ ἐξ ἀνηιβῆς ἥδοντα Λουκάς, κρατερὰ μ’ ἐκάλυψεν ἀμννεῖς.

ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΈΝΟ ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ:μή μόνος τελέλομαι ταῦτα κἄστι τις αὐτός: Κατ’ εἶθ’ αὐτὰ δέ, τὰ πάντα ἐάσας πατούμενος τῷ Κεραυνόν, ἥ τ’ ἐξ ἀνηιβῆς ἥδοντα Λουκάς, κρατερὰ μ’ ἐκάλυψεν ἀμννεῖς.

From the theory of the dialogue according to the classical interpretation by W.N. Hofweber:

BASILEUS. Ask a question about people, about what's going on right now.

MEN. First tell me one thing, sir. Are you Basileus?

BASILEUS. Yes, according to the antique principle, "to the king belong the young men" [Eur. "Her." 950], young men are under his care; and show of respect, and reverence, and modesty, and obedience – these are what young men should show the leader put in charge of them. 
For there is nothing, Menaechmus, in what you say. That's what laws all have in common.

But you did not understand these basics, my son. I hear the voice of someone who is deeply angry, kicking up a fuss about evil deeds and that son of Pheretiades’ having behaved insolently. Seeing his guest hungry and parched, he'd keep the best food for himself, flaunting it now, and if he does catch wind of a win-win situation, it has to be his way.

PLEISTHENES. Miserable sick man, whom the gods (who delight in quarrels) have sent as a chosen messenger into the world of mortals! What a dreadful state I see you in! How strength and youth have abandoned you! Before you had desired death by gods' reckoning. You had surrendered completely to feasts and games, emptied the table, and were rewarded with all sorts of gifts. What you won was pride! Isn't that so? Weren't you tickled by the golden tinkle and the bracelets filled with dangling pearls? 
What kids enjoy so much, didn't all this make you grow ever stronger and firmer? In a little while you used up the running down the track! Your empty belly always sent you out with spears and your running contests; these are the kind that lead the races. Always to no avail, someone else seemingly was running out in front, never giving up hope of winning once again. You were a winner, but you went for it again and again and came out first in what seemed to be the next to last place, which made you a big sinner against the god who watches over Thessalian horses. The chosen one, though, went on ahead and gained the prize, becoming the winner. This was quite the thing to see! But your futile squandering made you so embittered, that you blasphemed against the gods and fought with everyone and threw yourself on your parents' grave.

And what about your mother? After nursing you and bringing you up, loving you, not benefiting from a good life but always in misery, did you stay quiet when you saw her with nothing? Didn't you figure that she was suffering wretchedly because of

prediction.prompt:
Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

From the theory of the dialogue according to the classical interpretation by W.N. Hofweber:

BASILEUS. Ask a question about people, about what's going on right now.

MEN. First tell me one thing, sir. Are you Basileus?

BASILEUS. Yes, according to the antique principle, "to the king belong the young men" [Eur. "Her." 950], young men are under his care; and show of respect, and reverence, and modesty, and obedience – these are what young men should show the leader put in charge of them. 
For there is nothing, Menaechmus, in what you say. That's what laws all have in common.

But you did not understand these basics, my son. I hear the voice of someone who is deeply angry, kicking up a fuss about evil deeds and that son of Pheretiades’ having behaved insolently. Seeing his guest hungry and parched, he'd keep the best food for himself, flaunting it now, and if he does catch wind of a win-win situation, it has to be his way.

PLEISTHENES. Miserable sick man, whom the gods (who delight in quarrels) have sent as a chosen messenger into the world of mortals! What a dreadful state I see you in! How strength and youth have abandoned you! Before you had desired death by gods' reckoning. You had surrendered completely to feasts and games, emptied the table, and were rewarded with all sorts of gifts. What you won was pride! Isn't that so? Weren't you tickled by the golden tinkle and the bracelets filled with dangling pearls? 
What kids enjoy so much, didn't all this make you grow ever stronger and firmer? In a little while you used up the running down the track! Your empty belly always sent you out with spears and your running contests; these are the kind that lead the races. Always to no avail, someone else seemingly was running out in front, never giving up hope of winning once again. You were a winner, but you went for it again and again and came out first in what seemed to be the next to last place, which made you a big sinner against the god who watches over Thessalian horses. The chosen one, though, went on ahead and gained the prize, becoming the winner. This was quite the thing to see! But your futile squandering made you so embittered, that you blasphemed against the gods and fought with everyone and threw yourself on your parents' grave.

And what about your mother? After nursing you and bringing you up, loving you, not benefiting from a good life but always in misery, did you stay quiet when you saw her with nothing? Didn't you figure that she was suffering wretchedly because of

"dei μὲν, & παῖ Λἀρτίου, δέδορκά os πεῖράν τιν’ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῷῶ Αίαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτ’ ἔνδον, εἴτ’ οὐκ ἔνδον· εὖ δέ σ’ ἐκφέρει κυνὸς Λακαίνης ὥς τις εὔρινος βάσις. ἔνδον γὰρ ἀνὴρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει κάρα στάζων ἱδρῶτι nal χέρας ξιφοκτόνους. καί σ’ οὐδὲν εἴσω τῆςδε παπταίνειν πύλης ἔτ’ ἔργον ἐστὶν, ἐννέπειν δ’ ὅτου χάριν σπουδὴν Edov τήνδ’, ὡς παρ’ εἰδυίας μάθῃς. ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ὦ φθέγμ’ Ἀθάνας, φιλτάτης ἐμοὶ θεῶν, ὡς εὐμαθές σου, κἂν ἄποπτος 6, ὅμως φώνημ’ ἀκούω καὶ ξυναρπάζω φρενὶ, χαλκοστόμου κώδωνος ὡς Τυρσηνικῆς. καὶ νῦν ἐπέγνως εὖ μ’ ἐπ’ ἀνδρὶ δυςμενεῖ βάσιν κυκλοῦντ’, Αἴαντι τῷ σακεςφόρῳ.

From the theory of the dialogue according to the classical interpretation by W.N. Hofweber:

BASILEUS. Ask a question about people, about what's going on right now.

MEN. First tell me one thing, sir. Are you Basileus?

BASILEUS. Yes, according to the antique principle, "to the king belong the young men" [Eur. "Her." 950], young men are under his care; and show of respect, and reverence, and modesty, and obedience – these are what young men should show the leader put in charge of them. 
For there is nothing, Menaechmus, in what you say. That's what laws all have in common.

But you did not understand these basics, my son. I hear the voice of someone who is deeply angry, kicking up a fuss about evil deeds and that son of Pheretiades’ having behaved insolently. Seeing his guest hungry and parched, he'd keep the best food for himself, flaunting it now, and if he does catch wind of a win-win situation, it has to be his way.

PLEISTHENES. Miserable sick man, whom the gods (who delight in quarrels) have sent as a chosen messenger into the world of mortals! What a dreadful state I see you in! How strength and youth have abandoned you! Before you had desired death by gods' reckoning. You had surrendered completely to feasts and games, emptied the table, and were rewarded with all sorts of gifts. What you won was pride! Isn't that so? Weren't you tickled by the golden tinkle and the bracelets filled with dangling pearls? 
What kids enjoy so much, didn't all this make you grow ever stronger and firmer? In a little while you used up the running down the track! Your empty belly always sent you out with spears and your running contests; these are the kind that lead the races. Always to no avail, someone else seemingly was running out in front, never giving up hope of winning once again. You were a winner, but you went for it again and again and came out first in what seemed to be the next to last place, which made you a big sinner against the god who watches over Thessalian horses. The chosen one, though, went on ahead and gained the prize, becoming the winner. This was quite the thing to see! But your futile squandering made you so embittered, that you blasphemed against the gods and fought with everyone and threw yourself on your parents' grave.

And what about your mother? After nursing you and bringing you up, loving you, not benefiting from a good life but always in misery, did you stay quiet when you saw her with nothing? Didn't you figure that she was suffering wretchedly because of

Ὁρᾷς, Ὀδυσσεῦ, τὴν θεῶν ἰσχὺν, ὅση ; τούτου τίς ἄν σοι τἀνδρὸς ἢ προνούστερος, ἢ δρᾷν ἀμείνων εὑρέθη τὰ καίρια ; ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ἐγὼ μὲν οὐδέν’ οἶδ’· ἐποικτείρω δέ νιν δύστηνον ἔμπας, καίπερ ὄντα δυςμενῆ, ὁθούνεκ’ ἄτῃ ξυγκατέζευκται κακῇ, οὐδὲν τὸ τούτου μᾶλλον ἢ τοὐμὸν σκοπῶν. ὁρῶ γὰρ ἡμᾶς οὐδὲν ὄντας ἄλλο πλὴν εἴδωλ’, ὅσοιπερ ζῶμεν, ἢ κούφην σκιάν. ΑΘΗΝΑ. prediction.prompt:
Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

Moreover, citing examples from his Attic experience, the kind assigned a fort-like promontory as its home (as in Aristophanes' humorous Three-Esguelles epithet προβλήτης at 1143–1144) brings us to the attention of another feature in the present landscape. The Lemnians are talking about having driven back from Lemnos, on this Adriatic island, the invaders of that time, the Paphlagonians. Now here is an important verse that bears on the verb choice, for though ἄ̑ρξω appears in this verse as it does elsewhere throughout the Iliad, at least once (V 53) the text there stands ἄ̑ρξέμενος, which in our IPA system looks exactly the same. One may legitimately ask what this difference, which is of mid stride in a word, means for the reading understood. For a translator, it allows barely imaginable luxuries. It displays the surprising (to me) fact that άρξόμενος functions as a synonym of ἄρξων, and that when άρξομενος (< áxoma) appears, it has the effect of an emphatic present tense, as indicated at Paton 50.3. We ask what modifiers might contribute to the sense in Paton's equation of the two forms. Could it be that ἄρξων: άρξομενος:: ἄρξων: ἄρξον? And there we arrive at the crux of the issue for us, for Homer employs ἄ̑ρξω with the dual imperative, having a dual subject. The grammatical principle at play in καταπέλτωσαν the two together (my translation), implying that it was not surprising to see ἄ̑ρξαμενος here (ἄ̑ρξαμενον is almost always found in epic at an enjambment), is matched by the noun the phrase in which it came (πρός Te λουτρὰ καὶ παρακτίους λειμῶνας, ὡς λύμαθ’ ἀγνίσας Ιπέλων ἐμη, βΑΡΕΙΑΝ (ἀγνίσας) translates ἀγνῶς, which refers to calm, peace. This is the first time that we have encountered the name ἴπελος in this context. Paton has Ιπέλων ἐμὰ: ΒΑΡΕΙΑΝ ἀγνίσας < ἄνδρας ἐμὰ βαρύτατ' ἀγάνα οὔτ’ ἄπελλα ἔθειρεν (14) a remark he cites in German translation. Ideally, one would translate that line as if it were Greek, and then quote the German. But this is impossible grammatically. The maneuver I have done here subtly flavored with references to warfare does not meet the challenge. ἀγνίσας is a form not at all familiar to me. What of Ἀγνίζω? Do I need to learn that form of an important word at the expense of ἀγνίσας plus the long references? We let the matter rest, and look carefully at the antecedent. Χορῶ πρὸς ἔργον· τοῦτό σοι δ’ ἐφίεμαι, τοιάνδ’ ἀεί μοι ξύμμαχον παρεστάναι. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Ὁρᾷς, Ὀδυσσεῦ, τὴν θεῶν ἰσχὺν, ὅση ; τούτου τίς ἄν σοι τἀνδρὸς ἢ προνούστερος, ἢ δρᾷν ἀμείνων εὑρέθη τὰ καίρια ; ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ἐγὼ μὲν οὐδέν’ οἶδ’· ἐποικτείρω δέ νιν δύστηνον ἔμπας, καίπερ ὄντα δυςμενῆ, ὁθούνεκ’ ἄτῃ ξυγκατέζευκται κακῇ, οὐδὲν τὸ τούτου μᾶλλον ἢ τοὐμὸν σκοπῶν. ὁρῶ γὰρ ἡμᾶς οὐδὲν ὄντας ἄλλο πλὴν εἴδωλ’, ὅσοιπερ ζῶμεν, ἢ κούφην σκιάν. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Τοιαῦτα τοίνυν εἰςορῶν, ὑπέρκοπον μηδέν ποτ’ εἴπῃς αὐτὸς εἰς θεοὺς ἔπος, μηδ’ ὄγκον ἄρῃς μηδέν’, εἴ τινος πλέον ἢ χειρὶ βρίθεις ἢ μακροῦ πλούτου βάθει. ὡς ἡμέρα κλίνει τε κἀνάγει πάλιν ἅπαντα τἀνθρώπεια· τοὺς δὲ σώφρονας θεοὶ φιλοῦσι καὶ στυγοῦσι τοὺς κακούς.

ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:
ΤΟ ΝΟΜΙΣΜΑ ΣΤΟ ΜΕΓΑΛΟΠΟΛΙΣ

At that time the demos of the Athenians in the Great Assembly [p275] was already in session every day. Its members had been divided into ten sections (phylai) of a hundred members each. Eventually thirty sections voted "yes", but two did not vote (one was absent and the other abstained). The president (epistates) of one side was Lycurgus; the others were Archestratus, Diocles, Chares, Myron, Procles, Myronides, Callimachus, Erastosthenes, Pasiteles, Aristocrates, Acumenus, Eubernus, Callicles, Antalcidas, Poliander. Of those who voted "yes", Poliander resisted the introduction of martial law (sitou centrōn) and kept asking that each of the proposals be submitted to the judgment of ten thousand members. He rejected out of hand a proposal concerning the return to the city hall of those left there as [voluntary] hostages, because of their aristocratic descent, when they would give the Athenians a great number of slaves for safekeeping. [p277]When the Thirty heard that message, they were very angry and arrested Poliander, Diocles and Chares ... Busied at the moment with the and other matters, after settling everything else, they decided at the magistrates (prytaneis)' request to send others to Eleusis with Poliander, Lycurgus and Diocles, and to take them to Eleusis to put them to death at a later time. From the … they kept Diocles and had no idea yet what to do with him. [p279] their wives; and they said that if [the widows of the dead men] caused no mischief, they would allow them to live and manage their property, but if they were to go all around pleading for vengeance for their dead husbands, they would have them captured and put to death.

When Eugenia heard this news, she killed herself in her own armchair; when Theano’s servant learned what had happened to Weinidas – who had been killed by the Eleven and not by the people – his life also ended. Theano slew herself by drowning. Pity for herself might well have seized them if anyone had compassion for their children, [who were] an orphaned girl belonging to a great man, a boy [almost] still a child. Coming from a classic commentary these words are compiled without comment: composed and used in this way, they are made up of parts of an interpretation with parts of the text transliterated into ancient Greek [only], and with other bits in other languages.

MULTIPLE TRANSLATIONS OF THE FUNERAL ORATION:

Words "For Editing:":
an old woman among enemies bereavements instead of gifts not worthy of acceptance

Words "For Editing:"
an old woman among enemies bereavements instead of gifts not worthy of acceptance

Words "For Editing:"
I, DEMOSTHENES, JOINED THE THIRTY, HAVING BEEN WELCOMED AS A COMRADE THROUGH THE DELIVERY OF SPEECH #1. I WAS ABLE TO REVEAL THE PLANS OF MY ENEMIES TO THEM AND WAS ELECTED BY THEM AS A MEMBER OF THE COUNCIL TO LEAD YOUR STATE IN THIS CARTEL WITH THEM.
Finally, having pried into the chests of the Megarean envoys clearly loaded with bribes, having seen you become addicted to Demadates’ money, having learned, furthermore, that Hyperides and his flute players were thinking of new ways for you foolishly to run after [other] great sums of money, in astonishment (aθοῦ), I was enthusiastically convinced by time to hand you over to the benefactors with gladness. This was no ignoble order: it was a matter involving the ancestral ways of the good ancestry toward the rest of the world, this profit, this bloodless battle, this saving (hēsuchios) of the ancestral rites and shrines [p91]
So it was necessary to provide ourselves a garrison, with you concordant, as we decided. Now, other states when they have foreign enemies make an ally out of the slaves so that they would be more at ease under the hard circumstances of war

The point here, Socrates is, is that we were impressed to hear that you consider that no-one among us has no virtue in any way at all, on the contrary, you also think that we are scared of you and big our eye 009 and as any valiant men. Us godlings are scared! So our virtue is just the shadows that we cast. (Platonides, "Plato's Waning Day," Alcibiades I 123-138). So, I am not sure what lesson exactly Xenophondraws from this (88-89). His wording at 88-89 heavily suggest that he wants to say this to gloss over his previous declaration on virtue, or, to argue that almost always people (including us, old men, including Socrates) are misguided due to their ignorance. The End.

Moreover, citing examples from his Attic experience, the kind assigned a fort-like promontory as its home (as in Aristophanes' humorous Three-Esguelles epithet προβλήτης at 1143–1144) brings us to the attention of another feature in the present landscape. The Lemnians are talking about having driven back from Lemnos, on this Adriatic island, the invaders of that time, the Paphlagonians. Now here is an important verse that bears on the verb choice, for though ἄ̑ρξω appears in this verse as it does elsewhere throughout the Iliad, at least once (V 53) the text there stands ἄ̑ρξέμενος, which in our IPA system looks exactly the same. One may legitimately ask what this difference, which is of mid stride in a word, means for the reading understood. For a translator, it allows barely imaginable luxuries. It displays the surprising (to me) fact that άρξόμενος functions as a synonym of ἄρξων, and that when άρξομενος (< áxoma) appears, it has the effect of an emphatic present tense, as indicated at Paton 50.3. We ask what modifiers might contribute to the sense in Paton's equation of the two forms. Could it be that ἄρξων: άρξομενος:: ἄρξων: ἄρξον? And there we arrive at the crux of the issue for us, for Homer employs ἄ̑ρξω with the dual imperative, having a dual subject. The grammatical principle at play in καταπέλτωσαν the two together (my translation), implying that it was not surprising to see ἄ̑ρξαμενος here (ἄ̑ρξαμενον is almost always found in epic at an enjambment), is matched by the noun the phrase in which it came (πρός Te λουτρὰ καὶ παρακτίους λειμῶνας, ὡς λύμαθ’ ἀγνίσας Ιπέλων ἐμη, βΑΡΕΙΑΝ (ἀγνίσας) translates ἀγνῶς, which refers to calm, peace. ΑΘΗΝΑ.

ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:
ΤΟ ΝΟΜΙΣΜΑ ΣΤΟ ΜΕΓΑΛΟΠΟΛΙΣ

At that time the demos of the Athenians in the Great Assembly [p275] was already in session every day. Its members had been divided into ten sections (phylai) of a hundred members each. Eventually thirty sections voted "yes", but two did not vote (one was absent and the other abstained). The president (epistates) of one side was Lycurgus; the others were Archestratus, Diocles, Chares, Myron, Procles, Myronides, Callimachus, Erastosthenes, Pasiteles, Aristocrates, Acumenus, Eubernus, Callicles, Antalcidas, Poliander. Of those who voted "yes", Poliander resisted the introduction of martial law (sitou centrōn) and kept asking that each of the proposals be submitted to the judgment of ten thousand members. He rejected out of hand a proposal concerning the return to the city hall of those left there as [voluntary] hostages, because of their aristocratic descent, when they would give the Athenians a great number of slaves for safekeeping. [p277]When the Thirty heard that message, they were very angry and arrested Poliander, Diocles and Chares ... Busied at the moment with the and other matters, after settling everything else, they decided at the magistrates (prytaneis)' request to send others to Eleusis with Poliander, Lycurgus and Diocles, and to take them to Eleusis to put them to death at a later time. From the … they kept Diocles and had no idea yet what to do with him. [p279] their wives; and they said that if [the widows of the dead men] caused no mischief, they would allow them to live and manage their property, but if they were to go all around pleading for vengeance for their dead husbands, they would have them captured and put to death.

When Eugenia heard this news, she killed herself in her own armchair; when Theano’s servant learned what had happened to Weinidas – who had been killed by the Eleven and not by the people – his life also ended. Theano slew herself by drowning. Pity for herself might well have seized them if anyone had compassion for their children, [who were] an orphaned girl belonging to a great man, a boy [almost] still a child. Coming from a classic commentary these words are compiled without comment: composed and used in this way, they are made up of parts of an interpretation with parts of the text transliterated into ancient Greek [only], and with other bits in other languages.

MULTIPLE TRANSLATIONS OF THE FUNERAL ORATION:

Words "For Editing:":
an old woman among enemies bereavements instead of gifts not worthy of acceptance

Words "For Editing:"
an old woman among enemies bereavements instead of gifts not worthy of acceptance

Words "For Editing:"
I, DEMOSTHENES, JOINED THE THIRTY, HAVING BEEN WELCOMED AS A COMRADE THROUGH THE DELIVERY OF SPEECH #1. I WAS ABLE TO REVEAL THE PLANS OF MY ENEMIES TO THEM AND WAS ELECTED BY THEM AS A MEMBER OF THE COUNCIL TO LEAD YOUR STATE IN THIS CARTEL WITH THEM.
Finally, having pried into the chests of the Megarean envoys clearly loaded with bribes, having seen you become addicted to Demadates’ money, having learned, furthermore, that Hyperides and his flute players were thinking of new ways for you foolishly to run after [other] great sums of money, in astonishment (aθοῦ), I was enthusiastically convinced by time to hand you over to the benefactors with gladness. This was no ignoble order: it was a matter involving the ancestral ways of the good ancestry toward the rest of the world, this profit, this bloodless battle, this saving (hēsuchios) of the ancestral rites and shrines [p91]
So it was necessary to provide ourselves a garrison, with you concordant, as we decided. Now, other states when they have foreign enemies make an ally out of the slaves so that they would be more at ease under the hard circumstances of war

groundtruth.region: ΑΙΑΣ. Χαίρειν, Ἀθάνα, τἄλλ’ ἐγώ σ’ ἐφίεμαι, κεῖνος δὲ τίσει τήνδε κοὐκ ἄλλην δίκην. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Σὺ δ’ οὖν, ἐπειδὴ τέρψις ἥδε σοι τὸ δρᾷν, χρῶ χειρί· φείδου μηδὲν ὧνπερ ἐννοεῖς. ΑΙΑΣ. Χορῶ πρὸς ἔργον· τοῦτό σοι δ’ ἐφίεμαι, τοιάνδ’ ἀεί μοι ξύμμαχον παρεστάναι. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Ὁρᾷς, Ὀδυσσεῦ, τὴν θεῶν ἰσχὺν, ὅση ; τούτου τίς ἄν σοι τἀνδρὸς ἢ προνούστερος, ἢ δρᾷν ἀμείνων εὑρέθη τὰ καίρια ; ΟΔΥΣΣΕΥΣ. Ἐγὼ μὲν οὐδέν’ οἶδ’· ἐποικτείρω δέ νιν δύστηνον ἔμπας, καίπερ ὄντα δυςμενῆ, ὁθούνεκ’ ἄτῃ ξυγκατέζευκται κακῇ, οὐδὲν τὸ τούτου μᾶλλον ἢ τοὐμὸν σκοπῶν. ὁρῶ γὰρ ἡμᾶς οὐδὲν ὄντας ἄλλο πλὴν εἴδωλ’, ὅσοιπερ ζῶμεν, ἢ κούφην σκιάν. ΑΘΗΝΑ. Τοιαῦτα τοίνυν εἰςορῶν, ὑπέρκοπον μηδέν ποτ’ εἴπῃς αὐτὸς εἰς θεοὺς ἔπος, μηδ’ ὄγκον ἄρῃς μηδέν’, εἴ τινος πλέον ἢ χειρὶ βρίθεις ἢ μακροῦ πλούτου βάθει. ὡς ἡμέρα κλίνει τε κἀνάγει πάλιν ἅπαντα τἀνθρώπεια· τοὺς δὲ σώφρονας θεοὶ φιλοῦσι καὶ στυγοῦσι τοὺς κακούς.

prediction.region: I love this bit! Socrates, you know that we always impress how good it is and how many people marvel about (f oresteoroun = talk, i.e. this ) at seeing you regarding people who have great virtue as to saying they have no virtue in any way, while regarding people who commit great wickedness, we tell ourselves you did consider us to have virtue in some way. That's why I admire you so. But the words that you just said are amazing, and shock me thoroughly: you say that even if Erixenos hadn't been like so great at singing, all the same he could always have considered you to possess the virtue of some sort. That's really the ultimate strat[e]gy! It's so amazing, and from now on in Xenophonstories and Plotiad - remember that I was already fond of Plota[i]des, but now I [will] also think much of the Blot[a]des and also Dion[is]iades, the latter [who] having performed great virtue extraordinaire, went from that to meet the bad thing. I would wonder how is it possible to achieve the first, [and] only by virtue of achieving [] that to get the second? [As?] (you weave = tipotate literally, and of course it's also possible to weave in the sense of imerge and come out = Imergo kai exouo alla katathesi tin' ellehhia anagignoskomenov ki w[r]eed kai thews kai gignoske can be read in this context too,) man doesn't weave = doesn't immerge 0, that's all there is to say really, and no more than this except one exception, that is, unhappy manweaving = immerge except the unfortunate man we mentioned earlier who did a horridly bad thing, thus earning him a greater penalty. [] Of course, [that's not surprising] at all! The point here, Socrates is, is that we were impressed to hear that you consider that no-one among us has no virtue in any way at all, on the contrary, you also think that we are scared of you and big our eye 009 and as any valiant men. Us godlings are scared! So our virtue is just the shadows that we cast. (Platonides, "Plato's Waning Day," Alcibiades I 123-138). So, I am not sure what lesson exactly Xenophondraws from this (88-89). His wording at 88-89 heavily suggest that he wants to say this to gloss over his previous declaration on virtue, or, to argue that almost always people (including us, old men, including Socrates) are misguided due to their ignorance. Why? "AQOS = _ÕEÉ, PESH-EI = «ἡ ψó-ισμασία, EI- POLI? = ἦμεν &͵ (οὐκ ἦμαρκέτο) &µ ΧΟ-ΡΕΣ = ὤ-δωσα-μεν" The cosmos we live, is a sphere. We are spheres, and there are other bigger spheres around us. The biggest sphere is the one of the Olympiacs, but there is God above Olympiacs. At the tip of the ray of the sun, I think, everything is God. I think Plato. Xenophon says something different. C+. The End.

prediction.line:
ΑΘΗΝΑ.

ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:
ΤΟ ΝΟΜΙΣΜΑ ΣΤΟ ΜΕΓΑΛΟΠΟΛΙΣ

At that time the demos of the Athenians in the Great Assembly [p275] was already in session every day. Its members had been divided into ten sections (phylai) of a hundred members each. Eventually thirty sections voted "yes", but two did not vote (one was absent and the other abstained). The president (epistates) of one side was Lycurgus; the others were Archestratus, Diocles, Chares, Myron, Procles, Myronides, Callimachus, Erastosthenes, Pasiteles, Aristocrates, Acumenus, Eubernus, Callicles, Antalcidas, Poliander. Of those who voted "yes", Poliander resisted the introduction of martial law (sitou centrōn) and kept asking that each of the proposals be submitted to the judgment of ten thousand members. He rejected out of hand a proposal concerning the return to the city hall of those left there as [voluntary] hostages, because of their aristocratic descent, when they would give the Athenians a great number of slaves for safekeeping. [p277]When the Thirty heard that message, they were very angry and arrested Poliander, Diocles and Chares ... Busied at the moment with the and other matters, after settling everything else, they decided at the magistrates (prytaneis)' request to send others to Eleusis with Poliander, Lycurgus and Diocles, and to take them to Eleusis to put them to death at a later time. From the … they kept Diocles and had no idea yet what to do with him. [p279] their wives; and they said that if [the widows of the dead men] caused no mischief, they would allow them to live and manage their property, but if they were to go all around pleading for vengeance for their dead husbands, they would have them captured and put to death.

When Eugenia heard this news, she killed herself in her own armchair; when Theano’s servant learned what had happened to Weinidas – who had been killed by the Eleven and not by the people – his life also ended. Theano slew herself by drowning. Pity for herself might well have seized them if anyone had compassion for their children, [who were] an orphaned girl belonging to a great man, a boy [almost] still a child. Coming from a classic commentary these words are compiled without comment: composed and used in this way, they are made up of parts of an interpretation with parts of the text transliterated into ancient Greek [only], and with other bits in other languages.

MULTIPLE TRANSLATIONS OF THE FUNERAL ORATION:

Words "For Editing:":
an old woman among enemies bereavements instead of gifts not worthy of acceptance

Words "For Editing:"
an old woman among enemies bereavements instead of gifts not worthy of acceptance

Words "For Editing:"
I, DEMOSTHENES, JOINED THE THIRTY, HAVING BEEN WELCOMED AS A COMRADE THROUGH THE DELIVERY OF SPEECH #1. I WAS ABLE TO REVEAL THE PLANS OF MY ENEMIES TO THEM AND WAS ELECTED BY THEM AS A MEMBER OF THE COUNCIL TO LEAD YOUR STATE IN THIS CARTEL WITH THEM.
Finally, having pried into the chests of the Megarean envoys clearly loaded with bribes, having seen you become addicted to Demadates’ money, having learned, furthermore, that Hyperides and his flute players were thinking of new ways for you foolishly to run after [other] great sums of money, in astonishment (aθοῦ), I was enthusiastically convinced by time to hand you over to the benefactors with gladness. This was no ignoble order: it was a matter involving the ancestral ways of the good ancestry toward the rest of the world, this profit, this bloodless battle, this saving (hēsuchios) of the ancestral rites and shrines [p91]
So it was necessary to provide ourselves a garrison, with you concordant, as we decided. Now, other states when they have foreign enemies make an ally out of the slaves so that they would be more at ease under the hard circumstances of war

ΤΟ ΝΟΜΙΣΜΑ ΣΤΟ ΜΕΓΑΛΟΠΟΛΙΣ

At that time the demos of the Athenians in the Great Assembly [p275] was already in session every day. Its members had been divided into ten sections (phylai) of a hundred members each. Eventually thirty sections voted "yes", but two did not vote (one was absent and the other abstained). The president (epistates) of one side was Lycurgus; the others were Archestratus, Diocles, Chares, Myron, Procles, Myronides, Callimachus, Erastosthenes, Pasiteles, Aristocrates, Acumenus, Eubernus, Callicles, Antalcidas, Poliander. Of those who voted "yes", Poliander resisted the introduction of martial law (sitou centrōn) and kept asking that each of the proposals be submitted to the judgment of ten thousand members. He rejected out of hand a proposal concerning the return to the city hall of those left there as [voluntary] hostages, because of their aristocratic descent, when they would give the Athenians a great number of slaves for safekeeping. [p277]When the Thirty heard that message, they were very angry and arrested Poliander, Diocles and Chares ... Busied at the moment with the and other matters, after settling everything else, they decided at the magistrates (prytaneis)' request to send others to Eleusis with Poliander, Lycurgus and Diocles, and to take them to Eleusis to put them to death at a later time. From the … they kept Diocles and had no idea yet what to do with him. [p279] their wives; and they said that if [the widows of the dead men] caused no mischief, they would allow them to live and manage their property, but if they were to go all around pleading for vengeance for their dead husbands, they would have them captured and put to death.

When Eugenia heard this news, she killed herself in her own armchair; when Theano’s servant learned what had happened to Weinidas – who had been killed by the Eleven and not by the people – his life also ended. Theano slew herself by drowning. Pity for herself might well have seized them if anyone had compassion for their children, [who were] an orphaned girl belonging to a great man, a boy [almost] still a child. Finally, having pried into the chests of the Megarean envoys clearly loaded with bribes, having seen you become addicted to Demadates’ money, having learned, furthermore, that Hyperides and his flute players were thinking of new ways for you foolishly to run after [other] great sums of money, in astonishment (aθοῦ), I was enthusiastically convinced by time to hand you over to the benefactors with gladness. This was no ignoble order: it was a matter involving the ancestral ways of the good ancestry toward the rest of the world, this profit, this bloodless battle, this saving (hēsuchios) of the ancestral rites and shrines [p91]

Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

καὶ εἰ μέν τίς ἐκ ξανθῶν παρακείμενον βροτοῖσι θεῶν ὁδηγὸς ἐνῆν Ἴδην, τινί με πολλὰ τόνδε κακὰ καὶ ἀγαθὰ οἰκτείρων, 730 παρ’ ὀρόφων δ’ ὁδί, παρ’ ἄνδρ’ Ἀειδάων· τὸν δὲ πρὸς δρόμους αὐτὸν θῖναι σύκα μᾶλλον, ἢ ποιὸν ἀπορρήσειν δόρυ συγκοπέοντα, 735 ἢ τοῦ κόρυμβον ὄφρα πίμπλαμε λίθοις πρὸς ἄλλοις καὶ μαχομένοις ἑπταμόροιο πύρ. τοσούτ’ ἄγχι γὰρ οὐρανὸν πολὺ δεδηλωμέναι πεῖσαν Ἑλικῶνος ἄχνη, ὁπότ’ ὡς ἐξῆχθη κατ’ ἄρουραν πατρίου θεός· Μηδία καί μιν Ἴδην ἀλέσθαι ἐόντα πόλις γενεὰς ἐθίμησε τότε: The Gods, Ares God of War, and Kydoimos/Bootes; have begun the setting up of/for the capture of Atreus' wife, Chrysippus' wife and insult “Atreus very son in marriage to this woman” meaning Odysseus.

χάριν τοῖς αὑτῆς οὐκ ᾔδει ποτε μεθεπόμενος,
ἔτι παῖς γὰρ ἂν ἢν εὐλαβείτο μεθ’ ἡμέρας

ἄπειμι δὲ τῆσδε τῆς χώρας ἀμαθεστάτην

Β. ὅτι οὐδέποτε μᾶλλον ἔμην ὅτου κομιδήσατο χήρᾳ
ράδης προδαπάνης· ὄχημ’ ἐγὼ μόνον οἰόμην
δευτέρῃ τε καὶ βροτῶν σκήψεται ποταμός.
ἀλλ’ ἐκτός τοῦτον τὸν ποταμόν βαδίρομαι·
καιρὸς δή τις ἦλθε λήνεσσιν ὁμόσσαις.
νῦν δὲ πάντα τέκνον νῦν ᾦρθ’, αἴ κε βεβιωκώς
ὁρᾷς ἀδημονούμενον· ἀλλὰ σὺ πιστός ἠμείβεαι.
Μακεδάνεις δὲ θᾶκόν τε καὶ ἄλκιμον γένος
πᾶσαν οἰακίνην τὴν πόλιν μέσος τε δείκνυεν.
χυμὴ δ’ οὐκ ἐλοχίμων οὐδ’ ἀλαζόνητος ἕνεκα.
Τιμητός ἐστιν ἥ τ’ ἐτύμοισι χερῶν ἕρμαις,
καὶ βρέτας δώρους λάβειν ξυνόμενον μέτα
ὄλβια δώρα διὰ θεῶν ἀναμμένα.
Φίλος δ’ ἐν ἡδίω τοι ἐχθρός, ὅς σε μεμνῆσθαι
προὐλήψεται ἄκρον τ’ ἀσφαλῆ π

Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

Her tomb is to be seen at Mesatis, a stronghold in Thrace, on the road between Peiraieus and Macedon. She died at about ten years of age, having been reared amid the libations and sacrifices of her father. Do not suppose, however, that such things do honour to one at all: far otherwise is the opinion of the wise, which summons us away from these and curbs these human emotions: the judgements revealed by the belief in the gods are better. But why not insert the tribute of the children of Ilium to the daughter of Priam?

Her tomb is to be seen full of the lion’s footprints and marked by the body altogether as by an holy sign: the sands of Thrace stand as her Lesbian monument.
Respect this tomb, for it is not altogether the tomb of all men.

O sacred tomb of the daughter of Peleus, you are blessed in your children!

A maiden once I saw you, a maiden now I leave you!

Shush! Do not divulge the evil which I have warned you of; do not order the workmen to finish it early: I would rather cut them than risk letting the word, the name of Achilles, perish! It were wiser to abstain always from food than thus to deliver up to this reproach the grave of Achilles: let us restrain our breathing, that it may not reach the dead, that it may not rend the silence of the tomb!
As soon as the dead heard such a person was on his way,
the news brought tears to them. Did you see how they were ready to disclose
their grief? But not a sound escapes a living human being:
only occasionally, when she gets up, when she sits down to get some rest
does the heart feel the grief, but not as often as among the dead.

Here the earth itself gives us consolation, showing to everyone
situated here how the dead seem like the living.
Now if you have lied against the dead and made them seem mortal,
saying beforehand that they are corpses and dead bodies,
then after what you have done imagine the punishment.

There are equal numbers of dead and living heroes,
strong warriors whom you have not seen yet: also there are for you to be seen
the grandsons of those who sleep here and are sitting near you.

They are lovely in their strength, they are gathered in groups.
Do you see that there is the shield of Euphorbus in the middle?
See there the son of Tydeus and with him the two Ajaxes!
Then also with Ajax is Menelaus, you can see him near by –
Semele’s son and Helen’s husband: their way leads further away
to the shore of this broad lake where Achilles and Patroclus await us.

Where is that Cycnus, the son of Pelops?
He too is truly here: as judge Hades has lodged in a friendly place

Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". prediction.prompt:
Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

τῶν μεγάλων Δαναῶν ὕπο κλῃζομέναν,
ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΈΝΟ ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ:
prediction.line:
εἰ πᾶσιν ἄνδρες δίδου λόγους τε τετράλους,
τοῖσιν ἐμοί τε ὁράσει καὶ ἄλλοις ἂν φαίνοιτο,
Ταρσεύς, ἐπίκουρος τῶν Κυζικηνῶν τε καὶ Ἀρκάδων.
Τὰ μὲν πάντων δὴ ξυνομώτων ὕπεται
Κορίνθιοι τε καὶ ξακουστοί Δαναῖοι.
Ἀρμενίων δὲ οὐδεὶς ἐνέθυε ταῖς θυγατρίσιν
Χαιρωνεύς, νέους δ’ οὐδαμώς θυγατέργας Ἀρκάδας,
μόχθους δὲ πατρίγοροι τιμῶσι καὶ κοσμίους.
Οὐδένα δὲ ζῶντα παρέτρεχε μηδένων ἀμφιβαλούμενον:
ἀκοὴν ξυνῷ κυδαλίμοις καὶ δέρμα πτωχόν ἐστί.
Χαλκείδας δὲ μόχθηκος οὐ κρῖναι τὰ μῆτιν ἐθέλεις:
ἐσφιγμένους φρενῶν καὶ περιπαίζοντας ἀτιμῶνται.
τῆς γὰρ ἑταίρας ἐπειδὰν δόμον ἐλθῇς ἑκάστῳ,
πλούσιῳ δὲ συχνοτρόφῳ καὶ ἰδὰν ἥκωσιν ἄλλοι.
γέλων δὲ πολὺς ἐπειπεῖν βαρυχούργων ὀρφανὸν
ἐξ ἐραστὰς ἧπαρ, καὶ σεῖ᾽ ὀρφανὸν αὐτοῖς ἔπαθεν.
ἔνιοι δὲ νὴ Δήμητρον δὴ τὴν φρέσκον ταρσὸν
ἔζοντες ἀνθρώπων ἐπανῃκεῖαν δαήμονά ποτε.

groundtruth.region: ΑΘΗΝΑ. ἈΕΙ μέν, ὦ παῖ Λαρτίου, δέδορκά σε πεῖράν τινʼ ἐχθρῶν ἁρπάσαι θηρώμενον· καὶ νῦν ἐπὶ σκηναῖς σε ναυτικαῖς ὁρῶ Αἴαντος, ἔνθα τάξιν ἐσχάτην ἔχει, πάλαι κυνηγετοῦντα καὶ μετρούμενον ἴχνη τὰ κείνου νεοχάραχθ’, ὅπως ἴδῃς εἴτʼ ἔνδον εἴτʼ οὐκ ἔνδον. εὖ δέ σʼ ἐκφέρει
prediction.prompt:
Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΈΝΟ ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ:
prediction.line:
ΑΘΗΝΑ.

ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:
ΤΟ ΝΟΜΙΣΜΑ ΣΤΟ ΜΕΓΑΛΟΠΟΛΙΣ

At that time the demos of the Athenians in the Great Assembly [p275] was already in session every day. Its members had been divided into ten sections (phylai) of a hundred members each. Eventually thirty sections voted "yes", but two did not vote (one was absent and the other abstained). The president (epistates) of one side was Lycurgus; the others were Archestratus, Diocles, Chares, Myron, Procles, Myronides, Callimachus, Erastosthenes, Pasiteles, Aristocrates, Acumenus, Eubernus, Callicles, Antalcidas, Poliander. Of those who voted "yes", Poliander resisted the introduction of martial law (sitou centrōn) and kept asking that each of the proposals be submitted to the judgment of ten thousand members. He rejected out of hand a proposal concerning the return to the city hall of those left there as [voluntary] hostages, because of their aristocratic descent, when they would give the Athenians a great number of slaves for safekeeping. [p277]When the Thirty heard that message, they were very angry and arrested Poliander, Diocles and Chares ... Busied at the moment with the and other matters, after settling everything else, they decided at the magistrates (prytaneis)' request to send others to Eleusis with Poliander, Lycurgus and Diocles, and to take them to Eleusis to put them to death at a later time. From the … they kept Diocles and had no idea yet what to do with him. [p279] their wives; and they said that if [the widows of the dead men] caused no mischief, they would allow them to live and manage their property, but if they were to go all around pleading for vengeance for their dead husbands, they would have them captured and put to death.

When Eugenia heard this news, she killed herself in her own armchair; when Theano’s servant learned what had happened to Weinidas – who had been killed by the Eleven and not by the people – his life also ended. Theano slew herself by drowning. Pity for herself might well have seized them if anyone had compassion for their children, [who were] an orphaned girl belonging to a great man, a boy [almost] still a child. ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:
ΤΟ ΝΟΜΙΣΜΑ ΣΤΟ ΜΕΓΑΛΟΠΟΛΙΣ

At that time the demos of the Athenians in the Great Assembly [p275] was already in session every day. Its members had been divided into ten sections (phylai) of a hundred members each. Eventually thirty sections voted "yes", but two did not vote (one was absent and the other abstained). The president (epistates) of one side was Lycurgus; the others were Archestratus, Diocles, Chares, Myron, Procles, Myronides, Callimachus, Erastosthenes, Pasiteles, Aristocrates, Acumenus, Eubernus, Callicles, Antalcidas, Poliander. Of those who voted "yes", Poliander resisted the introduction of martial law (sitou centrōn) and kept asking that each of the proposals be submitted to the judgment of ten thousand members. He rejected out of hand a proposal concerning the return to the city hall of those left there as [voluntary] hostages, because of their aristocratic descent, when they would give the Athenians a great number of slaves for safekeeping. [p277]When the Thirty heard that message, they were very angry and arrested Poliander, Diocles and Chares ... Busied at the moment with the and other matters, after settling everything else, they decided at the magistrates (prytaneis)' request to send others to Eleusis with Poliander, Lycurgus and Diocles, and to take them to Eleusis to put them to death at a later time. From the … they kept Diocles and had no idea yet what to do with him. [p279] their wives; and they said that if [the widows of the dead men] caused no mischief, they would allow them to live and manage their property, but if they were to go all around pleading for vengeance for their dead husbands, they would have them captured and put to death.

When Eugenia heard this news, she killed herself in her own armchair; when Theano’s servant learned what had happened to Weinidas – who had been killed by the Eleven and not by the people – his life also ended. Theano slew herself by drowning. Pity for herself might well have seized them if anyone had compassion for their children, [who were] an orphaned girl belonging to a great man, a boy [almost] still a child. prediction.prompt:
Βοηθήστε στην εξέταση και διόρθωση σφαλμάτων σε κείμενα που παράγονται από την αυτόματη μεταγραφή ιστορικών εγγράφων. Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

Doryphoros of Polykleitos, a famous statue of the naked ithyphallic athlete (because of his erect posture), is one of the first images of depiction of the nude in Western art.

In the 1870s, the ancient fragment discovered in 1863 at Olympia was bought by the Louvre Museum, where the statue is now part of the collection.

prediction.line:
ΑΘΗΝΑ.

ΚΕΊΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:
ΤΟ ΝΟΜΙΣΜΑ ΣΤΟ ΜΕΓΑΛΟΠΟΛΙΣ

At that time the demos of the Athenians in the Great Assembly [p275] was already in session every day. Its members had been divided into ten sections (phylai) of a hundred members each. Eventually thirty sections voted "yes", but two did not vote (one was absent and the other abstained). The president (epistates) of one side was Lycurgus; the others were Archestratus, Diocles, Chares, Myron, Procles, Myronides, Callimachus, Erastosthenes, Pasiteles, Aristocrates, Acumenus, Eubernus, Callicles, Antalcidas, Poliander. Of those who voted "yes", Poliander resisted the introduction of martial law (sitou centrōn) and kept asking that each of the proposals be submitted to the judgment of ten thousand members. He rejected out of hand a proposal concerning the return to the city hall of those left there as [voluntary] hostages, because of their aristocratic descent, when they would give the Athenians a great number of slaves for safekeeping. [p277]When the Thirty heard that message, they were very angry and arrested Poliander, Diocles and Chares ... Busied at the moment with the and other matters, after settling everything else, they decided at the magistrates (prytaneis)' request to send others to Eleusis with Poliander, Lycurgus and Diocles, and to take them to Eleusis to put them to death at a later time. From the … they kept Diocles and had no idea yet what to do with him. [p279] their wives; and they said that if [the widows of the dead men] caused no mischief, they would allow them to live and manage their property, but if they were to go all around pleading for vengeance for their dead husbands, they would have them captured and put to death.

When Eugenia heard this news, she killed herself in her own armchair; when Theano’s servant learned what had happened to Weinidas – who had been killed by the Eleven and not by the people – his life also ended. Theano slew herself by drowning. Pity for herself might well have seized them if anyone had compassion for their children, [who were] an orphaned girl belonging to a great man, a boy [almost] still a child. Coming from a classic commentary these words are compiled without comment: composed and used in this way, they are made up of parts of an interpretation with parts of the text transliterated into ancient Greek [only], and with other bits in other languages.

MULTIPLE TRANSLATIONS OF THE FUNERAL ORATION:

Words "For Editing:":
an old woman among enemies bereavements instead of gifts not worthy of acceptance

Words "For Editing:"
an old woman among enemies bereavements instead of gifts not worthy of acceptance

Words "For Editing:"
I, DEMOSTHENES, JOINED THE THIRTY, HAVING BEEN WELCOMED AS A COMRADE THROUGH THE DELIVERY OF SPEECH #1. I WAS ABLE TO REVEAL THE PLANS OF MY ENEMIES TO THEM AND WAS ELECTED BY THEM AS A MEMBER OF THE COUNCIL TO LEAD YOUR STATE IN THIS CARTEL WITH THEM.
Finally, having pried into the chests of the Megarean envoys clearly loaded with bribes, having seen you become addicted to Demadates’ money, having learned, furthermore, that Hyperides and his flute players were thinking of new ways for you foolishly to run after [other] great sums of money, in astonishment (aθοῦ), I was enthusiastically convinced by time to hand you over to the benefactors with gladness. This was no ignoble order: it was a matter involving the ancestral ways of the good ancestry toward the rest of the world, this profit, this bloodless battle, this saving (hēsuchios) of the ancestral rites and shrines [p91]
So it was necessary to provide ourselves a garrison, with you concordant, as we decided. Now, other states when they have foreign enemies make an ally out of the slaves so that they would be more at ease under the hard circumstances of war

groundtruth.region: μηδὲν φόβου πρόβλημα μηδ’ αἰδοῦς ἔχων. ἀλλ’ ἄνδρα χρή, κἂν σῶμα γεννήσῃ μέγα, δοκεῖν πεσεῖν ἂν κἂν ἀπὸ σμικροῦ κακοῦ. δέος γὰρ ᾧ πρόσεστιν αἰσχύνη θ’ ὁμοῦ, σωτηρίαν ἔχοντα τόνδ’ ἐπίστασο· ὅπου δ’ ὑβρίζειν δρᾶν θ’ ἃ βούλεται παρῇ, ταύτην νόμιζε τὴν πόλιν χρόνῳ ποτὲ ἐξ οὐρίων δραμοῦσαν ἐς βυθὸν πεσεῖν. ἀλλ’ ἑστάτω μοι καὶ δέος τι καίριον, καὶ μὴ δοκῶμεν, δρῶντες ἃν ἡδώμεθα, οὐκ ἀντιτίσειν αὖθις ἃν λυπώμεθα. ἕρπει παραλλὰξ ταῦτα· πρόσθεν οὗτος ἦν αἴθων ὑβριστής, νῦν δ’ ἐγὼ μέγ’ αὖ φρονῶ. καί σοι προφωνῶ τόνδε μὴ θάπτειν, ὅπως μὴ τόνδε θάπτων αὐτὸς εἰς ταφὰς πέσῃς. ΧΟ. Μενέλαε, μὴ γνώμας ὑποστήσας σοφὰς εἶτ’ αὐτὸς ἐν θανοῦσιν ὑβριστὴς γένῃ. ΤΕΥ. οὐκ ἄν ποτ’, ἄνδρες, ἄνδρα θαυμάσαιμ’ ἔτι, ὃς μηδὲν ὢν γοναῖσιν εἶθ’ ἁμαρτάνει,

Στόχος σας είναι να εξετάσετε προσεκτικά το ακόλουθο κείμενο και να διορθώσετε όλα τα λάθη που εισήγαγε το λογισμικό. Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.

Το κείμενο για διόρθωση προέρχεται από ένα κλασικό σχόλιο και αποτελείται μόνο από το μέρος του σχολιασμού, με μέρος του κειμένου στα αρχαία ελληνικά και άλλα σε άλλες γλώσσες. Το προς διόρθωση κείμενο εμφανίζεται μετά το τμήμα "ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ ΓΙΑ ΔΙΟΡΘΩΣΗ:". Παρακαλούμε τοποθετήστε τη διορθωμένη έκδοση του κειμένου μετά το τμήμα "ΔΙΟΡΘΩΜΕΝΟ ΚΕΙΜΕΝΟ:". Μην γράψετε τίποτε άλλο εκτός από το διορθωμένο κείμενο.
